ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: West Nile Virus (WNV) Encephalitis
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Confirmed by otolaryngologist; patient had encephalitis, fever, weakness, and sudden hearing loss consistent with WNV sequelae.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Idiopathic Sudden Sensorineural Hearing Loss
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Sudden onset SNHL is often idiopathic, but specific viral cause (WNV) was identified in this case.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Autoimmune Inner Ear Disease
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Considered due to bilateral nature of sudden loss, but less likely given the acute viral presentation.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Vascular Lesion
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Potential cause for sudden loss, but clinical history points to viral etiology.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Acoustic Neuroma / Vestibular Schwannoma
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Considered due to asymmetry, but bilateral sudden onset and recovery pattern favor viral/inflammatory cause.

ordered_list.rationale_short: To assess the degree, type, and configuration of the reported sudden hearing loss.
To evaluate speech reception thresholds and word recognition abilities, checking for retrocochlear signs.
To assess middle ear function and rule out conductive pathology.
To evaluate the acoustic reflex arc and screen for retrocochlear pathology.
To assess for Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV) given reports of vertigo.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Initial evaluation 2.5 weeks post-onset revealed asymmetric sensorineural hearing loss, worse in the left ear. Word recognition was disproportionately poor in the left ear, and acoustic reflexes were absent bilaterally, consistent with neural involvement from encephalitis.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Right ear: slight sloping to severe SNHL (20-80 dB HL). Left ear: moderately severe to severe flat SNHL (60-80 dB HL).

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: Right SRT 25 dB HL, WRS 80%. Left SRT 65 dB HL, WRS 32% (very poor).

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Follow-up at 2 months showed significant spontaneous recovery in the right ear to near-normal sensitivity in low frequencies. The left ear remained severe with very poor speech recognition (16%). Reflexes partially recovered.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Right ear: Improved to normal (250-1000 Hz) sloping to moderate/mild. Left ear: Slight sloping to severe SNHL (severe in highs).

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: Right SRT 20 dB HL, WRS 86%. Left SAT 35 dB HL, WRS 16%.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.result_summary: Ipsilateral present at 500/1000 Hz, absent at 2000/4000 Hz. Contralateral elevated or absent.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Follow-up at 9 months showed stable hearing thresholds. The patient reported vertigo, and Dix-Hallpike confirmed right BPPV. Left ear diplacusis and distortion persisted.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Right ear stable (normal to moderate). Left ear stable (severe SNHL).

tests.name: Dix-Hallpike test
tests.result_summary: Positive for right benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV).

proposed_items: Hearing aid trial (Left ear, Right ear, or Bilateral)
Cochlear Implant evaluation (Left ear) with bimodal fitting
Hearing Assistive Technology (HAT) such as FM system or remote microphone
counseling_actions: Explain the link between West Nile Virus encephalitis and sensorineural hearing loss
Discuss the prognosis of spontaneous recovery (observed in right ear) versus permanent damage (left ear)
Explain diplacusis ('tin can' distortion) as a result of inner ear damage
Counsel on BPPV and the Epley maneuver
Discuss advantages and disadvantages of amplification options including CIs and BiCROS

red_flags_present: Sudden onset bilateral sensorineural hearing loss
Associated neurological symptoms (aphasia, weakness, vision changes)

escalation.rationale_short: Medical management of sudden hearing loss and West Nile Virus sequelae; patient was already under ENT care.

follow_up_plan.objective: Monitor hearing stability and reconsider amplification if the patient decides to proceed.

expected_outcome: Amplification options were discussed, including left/right/bilateral hearing aids, right BICROS, and a cochlear implant in the left ear.
The patient was most interested in a cochlear implant, but insurance coverage was a barrier.
The patient decided to wait to determine how well he can compensate for his hearing loss before pursuing amplification.
